posts.text:
• Known as al-Sab‘ al-Mathani (seven oft-repeated verses).
• Called umm al-kitab (Mother of the Book) as it is the foundation of the Quran.
• Recited in every unit of the five daily prayers.
• A divine format of prayer taught by Allah.
• Allah responds to each segment of the surah.
• Emphasises supplication and its etiquettes.

• Al-Fatiha covers central themes of belief, worship, and guidance.
• Serves as a prayer, and the rest of the Quran is the answer from Allah.

• Declares the Quran as a book free from doubt.
• Discusses creation of Adam and mankind’s nature.
• Addresses the Children of Israel and their history.
• Story of the golden calf and the Sabbath violation.
• Lessons from Ibrahim and Ismail building the Kabah.

• Change of Qiblah to Makkah.
• Commands on belief, timekeeping, hypocrisy, Ayat al-Kursi.
• Guidelines on social laws: marriage, trade, justice, fasting, pilgrimage.
• Emphasises writing contracts, avoiding usury, and justice.
• States non-compulsion in religion.

• Allah testifies about His Oneness.
• The Quran contains both clear and allegorical verses.
• Islam is the only acceptable religion to Allah.
• Emphasis on dying as a Muslim.
• History of Maryam, Isa and Yahya.
• Those martyred in Allah’s cause are alive.
• Lessons from the Battle of Uhud.
• The Kabah as the first House of Worship.

• Laws on marriage, inheritance, and women’s rights.
• Repentance guidelines.
• Forbidden relations for marriage.
• Arbitration in family disputes.
• Prohibitions on alcohol.
• Obedience to the Prophet equals obedience to Allah.
• Guidelines for greeting, prayer timings, travel prayers.
• Warning against hypocrisy and polytheism.
• Jesus was not crucified but raised by Allah.
• Family and societal laws established.

• Defines halal and haram foods.
• Permits food and marriage with People of the Book.
• Ablution, ghusl, and tayammum instructions.
• Reminds Jews and Christians of earlier obligations.
• Warns against corruption and abuse of power.
• Punishments for theft and rebellion.
• Strict prohibition on alcohol and gambling.
• Miracles of Isa and his human status.

• Emphasises tawhid and rebukes shirk.
• Refutes baseless religious laws.
• Responds to accusations against the Prophet.
• Comfort for believers during hardship.
• Warns disbelievers and prohibits religious sectarianism.
• Proclaims that life and death are for Allah.

• Invitation to People of the Book.
• Warnings to those who rejected past prophets.
• Importance of wise da'wah.
• Dialogue of Paradise, Hell, and A'raf dwellers.
• Command to wear modest clothing and eat pure food.
• Mention of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ in the Torah and Gospel.
• Unity of mankind from a single soul.

• Battle of Badr: truth versus falsehood.
• Emphasises fighting for justice, not gains.
• Rules for warfare and treaties.

• Final policy on polytheists.
• Laws on war, peace, and hypocrisy.
• Campaign of Tabuk and exposing hypocrites.
• Zakah as a means of purification.
• Allah purchases the lives of believers.

• Allah is the sole Creator.
• False gods have no power or awareness.
• Messengers sent to all nations.
• Quran is a cure for spiritual illness.
• Stories of Nuh, Musa, and Yunus.
• Prohibition of forced conversion.

• Allah sustains all beings.
• Quran is the unforgeable message.
• Stories of Nuh, his son, and other prophets.
• Warning to rejecters of divine message.
• Good deeds erase sins.
• Freedom of choice given to mankind.

• All messengers were human.
• Story of Yusuf and his dua.
• All prophets had one unified message.
• Contrast between believers and disbelievers.
• Trust in Allah leads to success.
• Yusuf’s moral strength shines under trial.

• Quran is Allah’s revelation.
• Nature reflects Allah’s signs.
• Allah changes not the condition of a people unless they act.
• Dhikr brings peace to hearts.
• Messengers perform miracles only with Allah’s permission.

• Messengers spoke the language of their people.
• Allah is unaffected by disbelief.
• Satan only seduces, has no real power.
• Story of Ibrahim’s prayer in Muslim rituals.
• Warning to rejecters of revelation.

• Quran is safeguarded by Allah.
• Disbelievers’ regret on Judgement Day.
• Story of Adam and Satan’s refusal.
• Ibrahim receives news of a son.
• Al-Fatiha mentioned as ‘seven oft-repeated verses’.

• Signs of Allah in creation.
• Quran gives life to the soul.
• Commands justice, generosity, and modesty.
• Rights and wrongs of halal/haram are for Allah to decide.
• Ibrahim praised as a nation himself.

• Night Journey (Isra) of the Prophet.
• Quran and the Children of Israel.
• Adam and Iblis story.
• Allah’s blessings and scenes from the Hereafter.
• Miraculous nature and guidance of the Quran.

• Praise for Allah and guidance.
• Stories: People of the Cave, Musa and Khidr, Dhul-Qarnayn.
• Themes: trials of faith, wealth, knowledge, power.
• Endurance and reliance on divine help.

• Stories of Zakariya, Yahya, Maryam and Isa.
• Isa’s human status clarified.
• Ibrahim’s da’wah to his father.
• Life of believers vs disbelievers.
• Condemnation of attributing a son to Allah.

• Quran as a reminder for the God-fearing.
• Stories of Musa and Pharaoh.
• Satan’s temptation of Adam.
• Message of patience, prayer, and knowledge.
• Do not envy worldly riches.

• Creation has purpose, not play.
• Unity of God, refuting polytheism.
• All prophets were mortal.
• Ibrahim’s challenge to idolatry.
• All mankind is one brotherhood.

• Reality of the Last Hour.
• Rights in Masjid al-Haram.
• Hajj commanded by Ibrahim.
• Importance of sincerity in sacrifice.
• Permission for self-defence granted.
• Believers named Muslims in prior scriptures too.

• Characteristics of successful believers.
• Creation stages of humans.
• Prophets Nuh and Hud.
• Guidance to respond to evil with good.
• Life of this world is brief.

• Laws on adultery, slander, and Lian.
• Incident of Aisha and her innocence.
• Encouragement to marry and free slaves.
• Modesty for men and women.
• Allah is the Light of the heavens and earth.

• Quran distinguishes truth from falsehood.
• Disbelievers regret their rejection on the Day of Judgement.
• Quran revealed gradually with wisdom.
• Command to strive with the Quran.
• Description of righteous believers.

• Allah’s address to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ that he should not fret himself to death with grief for the people’s disbelief.
• Story of Musa, Pharaoh and deliverance of the children of Israel.
• Story of Ibrahim and his arguments against idol worshipping.
• The polytheists and their gods will both be toppled into Hellfire.
• Stories of Prophets Nuh, Hud, Saleh, Lut, Shuayb and their people.
• The Quran is revealed in the Arabic language.
• Satans descend on slandering sinners who listen to hearsay and are liars.

• The Quran is a guide and good news to the believers.
• Prophet Musa’s nine miracles were shown to Pharaoh and his people.
• Story of Prophet Sulayman and the Queen of Sheba.
• Stories of Prophets Saleh, and Lut and their people.
• The disbelievers actually doubt Allah’s power of creation.
• A sign from the signs, and a scene from the scenes of Doomsday.
• Those who accept guidance do so for their own good and those who reject and go astray, do so at their own peril.
• Three character types have been presented in this surah:
  • Pharaoh, his chiefs, the nation of Thamud and the people of Prophet Lut
  • Prophet Sulayman
  • Queen of Sheba

• The story of Pharaoh who plotted to kill all the male children of the Israelites.
• How Allah saved Musa and arranged for him to be brought up in Pharaoh’s own household.
• Prophet Musa as a youth, accidental killing of a man, his escape to Madyan, his marriage, his seeing a fire at Mount Tur, and his assignment as a messenger.
• The stories of previous generations are related in the Quran as an eye opener for the disbelievers to learn a lesson.
• The prophets cannot give guidance; it is Allah who gives guidance.
• On the Day of Judgement, disbelievers will wish that they had accepted guidance and become Muslims.
• Allah has not allowed the polytheists to assign His powers to whom they want.
• The story of Qarun, the legendary rich man.
• Allah’s commandment that the revelation of the Quran is His mercy; a believer should let no one turn him away from it.

• Allah tests the believers to see who is truthful and who is a liar.
• Be kind to parents but do not obey them in matters of polytheism.
• Those who say: ‘Follow us, we will bear your burden on the Day of Judgement,’ are liars.
• Prophet Nuh admonished his people for 950 years not to engage in polytheism.
• Prophet Ibrahim admonished his people not to engage in polytheism, for which they tried to burn him alive, but Allah saved him.
• The nations of Ad, Thamud, Madyan and Pharaoh rejected the messengers of Allah, as a result Allah destroyed them all.
• Parable of those who take protectors other than Allah, is that of the dwelling of a spider and the fact that the weakest of all the dwellings is the dwelling of a spider.

• The defeat of the Romans (Christians) at the hands of the Persians (Pagans) was considered by Makkans a sign of the Muslims’ defeat at the hands of Arab disbelievers.
• Prophecy of the Roman victory against the Persians and the Muslim victory against the disbelievers.
• Allah has originated the creation and He will resurrect the dead for the Final Judgement.
• Creation of man, his consort, heaven, earth, language, colours, sleep, quest for work, lightning, rain and growth of vegetation – all are signs from Allah.
• Wrongdoers are those who are led by their own desires without real knowledge.
• True faith versus sects and polytheism.
• Commandment to give relatives their due and take care of the poor and travellers in need.
• Mischief on earth is due to man’s own misdeeds.
• Allah tells the Prophet: ‘O Prophet! You cannot make the dead hear you.’

• The Quran is a book of wisdom and a blessing for the righteous.
• Luqman’s advice to his son not to commit shirk.
• Rights of the mother and the parents.
• Not to obey parents if they ask you to commit shirk.
• Islamic moral behaviour and interaction.
• The main reason for misguidance is the blind following of one’s forefathers.
• If all trees were pens and oceans ink, Allah’s words could not be put to writing.
• Allah is the only Reality. All others whom people invoke besides Him are false.
• Mankind, fear that Day when not even a father shall avail his son, nor a son his father, let not Satan deceive you concerning this fact.

• The Quran is beyond all doubt and is sent to warn those people to whom no warner has come before.
• On the Day of Judgement, the disbelievers shall believe but that belief will be of no benefit to them.
• There is a special reward for those who forsake their beds and invoke their Lord with fear and hope, and spend in charity.
• The Quran is similar to the book which was given to Prophet Musa.

• Fear Allah and do not obey the disbelievers and the hypocrites.
• Laws relating to divorce and status of an adopted son.
• By word of mouth, neither your wives become your real mothers nor your adopted sons your real sons.
• Prophet’s wives are declared to be the mothers of all believers.
• Blood relations have greater claims than others in the Book of Allah.
• Battle of the Trench (Ahzab).
• Favours of Allah.
• Attitudes of the hypocrites.
• Non participants are declared to have no faith at all and that all their deeds are void.
• The life of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ is declared to be a model for all.
• Admonition to the wives of the Prophet.
• It is not befitting for the believers to have options in what has been decided by Allah and His Messenger.
• Commandment to the Prophet to marry the divorced wife of his adopted son.
• Prophet Muhammad ﷺ is not the father of any of your men but a messenger and seal of prophethood.
• Etiquettes concerning the visits to the Prophet’s household.
• Allah Himself and His angels send blessings on the Prophet, and the believers are instructed to do the same.
• Dress code for women.
• The trust of Allah was presented to the heavens, the earth and the mountains: they refused to take that responsibility but man took it.

• The Day of Resurrection is sure to come for Allah’s judgement to reward the believers and punish the disbelievers.
• Those who do not believe in the Hereafter are doomed.
• The mountains and birds used to sing Allah’s praises with Prophet Dawud.
• Allah subjected the winds and jinns to Prophet Sulayman.
• Intercession before Allah can not avail anyone except for whom He permits.
• Muhammad ﷺ is sent as a messenger for the whole of mankind.
• Wealth and children are a test to whom they are given.
• Whatever you spend in charity, Allah will pay you back in full.
• The truth has come, falsehood neither originates nor restores anything.
• On the Day of Judgement disbelievers will wish that they were believers.

• None can award or withhold blessings besides Allah.
• Satan is your enemy, so take him as such.
• The person who considers his evil deeds to be good deeds cannot be guided to the right path.
• Real honour is in being obedient to Allah.
• Mankind is in need of Allah while He is not in need of anyone.
• None can make those who are buried in the grave hear you.
• Those who recite the Quran, establish salah and give zakah may hope for Allah’s blessings and reward.
• Allah has not sent any Book which has a provision of shirk.
• Plotting evil recoils none but the author of it.
• If Allah was to punish people for their wrongdoing, He would have not left even an animal around them.

• The Quran is revealed by Allah to warn people and establish charge-sheet against the disbelievers.
• Allah has created all things in pairs.
• The day, night, sun and moon, all are being regulated by Allah.
• Scenes from the Day of Judgement:
  • Allah’s greetings to the residents of Paradise
  • Allah’s address to the sinners
  • Hands and feet shall bear witness
• All human beings shall be raised back to life again on the Day of Judgement for accountability of their deeds.
• Inspiration for those engaged in daawah and reform.

• Allah Himself testifies that your God is one and the satans do not have any access to the exalted assembly of angels.
• Life in the Hereafter and the Day of Judgement are real.
• Scenes from the Day of Judgement:
  • A dialogue between the followers and the leaders who mislead them
  • A view from the scenes of Paradise
  • A conversation between the residents of Paradise
  • A view from the scenes of Hellfire
• Prayer of Prophet Nuh and Allah’s response.
• The story of Prophet Ibrahim:
  • He questioned his people for worshipping idols
  • His people threw him the furnace, but Allah saved him
  • He prayed for a son and Allah granted him a son
  • Allah tested Ibrahim by asking him to offer the sacrifice of his only son and he passed the test
• Prophethood of Musa, Harun, Ilyas and Lut.
• Story of Prophet Yunus.
• Allah has promised to help His messengers.

• The Quran is full of admonition. The disbelievers are in sheer arrogance for calling the Prophet a liar.
• Story of Prophet Dawud:
  • The mountains and birds used to sing with him, glorifying Allah
  • The litigants who came to him for a decision
• Allah has not created the heavens and earth in vain.
• Story of Prophet Sulayman:
  • His inspection of steeds which were to be used in warfare
  • His prayer to grant him a kingdom which has not been granted to any one
• Story of Ayub, his sickness, patience and relief.
• Story of Adam and disobedience of Satan.

• The polytheists justify their worship of idols saying: ‘It brings us closer to Allah.’
• On the Day of Judgement no one shall bear the burden of others.
• Believers who cannot practise their faith should migrate to places where they can.
• Real losers are those who lose their souls and families on the Day of Judgement.
• No one can rescue the one against whom a punishment has been decreed.
• The Quran is consistent yet it repeats the teachings in different ways.
• Allah has cited every kind of example in the Quran so that people may clearly understand and reflect.
• Who can be more wicked than the one who invents a lie against Allah.
• Those who have transgressed against their souls should not despair of Allah’s mercy, they should repent while they can.
• On the Day of Judgement, everyone’s book of deeds shall be laid open and justice shall be done with all fairness.

• The angels who bear the throne of Allah pray for those humans who repent and follow the right way.
• A scene from the Day of Judgement.
• Allah knows the furtive looks and secret thoughts.
• Story of Prophet Musa, Pharaoh, Haman and Qarun.
• An excellent speech of one of the relatives of Pharaoh in favour of Prophet Musa.
• Pharaoh plotted against that relative, who was a believer, but Allah saved him and destroyed the people of Pharaoh, and now they are presented before the fire of Hell every morning and evening.
• Allah says: ‘Call me, I will answer your prayers.’
• No one has the right to be worshipped except Allah.
• Those who argue about the revelations of Allah will soon find out the Truth.
• Allah has sent many messengers before Muhammad ﷺ: of them some are mentioned in the Quran and some are not.
• Belief after seeing the punishment of Allah is of no avail to the disbelievers.

• The Quran was revealed to give admonition.
• Woe to those who deny the Hereafter and do not pay zakah.
• Story of the creation of earth, mountains, seas, skies and heavens.
• Example of Allah’s scourge upon the nations of Ad and Thamud.
• On the Day of Judgement, man’s own ears, eyes and skin will bear witness against him relating to his misdeeds.
• Those who say their God is Allah and stay firm on it, have angels assigned for their protection.
• The best in speech is the one who calls people towards Allah, does good deeds and says, ‘I am a Muslim.’
• The message which is revealed to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ is the same message which was revealed to previous prophets.
• The Quran is a guide and healing for the believers. It is similar to the Scripture given to Prophet Musa.

• The heaven might have broken apart from above those who elevate Allah’s creatures to His level if angels were not begging for forgiveness for them.
• Islam is the same religion which was enjoined on Nuh, Ibrahim, Musa and Isa.
• He who desires the harvest in the Hereafter shall be given manifold and he who desires it in this life shall be given a portion here but shall have no share in the Hereafter.
• Whatever misfortune befall people, are the result of their own misdeeds.
• True believers are those who establish salah, give charity and defend themselves when oppressed.
• The real losers are those who will lose on the Day of Resurrection.
• It is Allah who gives daughters and sons as He pleases.
• It is not for any human being that Allah should speak to him face to face.

• The Quran is a transcript from the Mother-Book which is in Allah’s keeping.
• Supplication before riding a conveyance.
• Creed of the polytheists that angels are female divinities is false.
• An example of Prophet Ibrahim who recognised the oneness of Allah and rejected polytheism using his common sense and observing His signs in nature.
• If it were not that all mankind will become one race of disbelievers, Allah would have given the disbelievers houses which were made with sterling silver.
• He who turns away from the remembrance of Allah, Allah appoints a satan to be his intimate friend.
• Hold fast to the Quran if you want to be rightly guided.
• Isa was no more than a mortal whom Allah favoured and made an example for the Children of Israel.
• Prophet Muhammad instructed to tell the Christians: ‘If Allah had a son, I would have been the first one to worship him.’

• Allah has revealed this Quran in the blessed night (Laylat-ul-Qadr).
• The Quran itself bears testimony that it is from Allah.
• Lessons to be learned from the story of Prophet Musa and the people of Pharaoh.
• Allah saved the Children of Israel and chose them over the nations of the world in spite of their weaknesses.
• Food and drink for the sinners in Hell compared to food and entertainment for the righteous in Paradise.

• If the disbelievers do not believe in Allah and His revelations then in what report will they believe!
• Allah has subjected the seas and all that is between the heavens and the earth for human beings.
• Israelites made sects in their religion even after knowledge had come to them through the Torah.
• Allah is the Protector of righteous people.
• He that makes his own desires as his god, Allah will let him go astray and set a seal upon his ears and heart.
• Allah’s address to the disbelievers on the Day of Judgement.

• The deities whom polytheists invoke are not even aware that they are being invoked.
• The Quran is the word of Allah, not of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.
• The Prophet is but a plain warner.
• The Quran confirms the revelation of the Torah given to Prophet Musa.
• Those who treat their parents with kindness shall be rewarded and those who rebuke their parents shall be punished.
• No deity can save people from the wrath of Allah.
• A group of jinns embraced Islam after hearing the Quran.
• Proclaim the message of Allah and bear with the disbelievers patiently.

• Allah invalidates the deeds of the disbelievers.
• In war, thoroughly subdue the unbelievers before taking them as prisoners of war.
• If you help the cause of Allah, Allah will help and protect you.
• True believers do not follow their own desires in matters of faith.
• Promise of obedience and good talk which is not followed by action is disliked.
• War captives should be freed unconditionally or after giving ransom.
• Allah put the believers to test to know the valiant and the resolute.
• In cases of war, Allah is on the side of the true believers.
• Do not be miserly if you are asked to give in the cause of Allah.

• Allah granted the Muslims a clear victory through the Treaty of Hudaibiyah.
• Swearing allegiance to the Prophet was considered swearing allegiance to Allah and Allah was well pleased with their actions.
• Only the blind, lame and sick are exempt from war.
• A vision to conquer Makkah was shown to the Prophet.
• Characteristics of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ and his followers.
• Strategy of peace and stability.

• Instruction to lower one’s voice in the presence of the Prophet.
• Make peace between the believers if they fight among themselves.
• Islamic etiquettes of moral behaviour:
  • Do not laugh at one another
  • Do not defame one another through sarcastic remarks
  • Do not call one another by offensive nicknames
  • Avoid immoderate suspicions, for in some cases it is a sin
  • Do not spy on one another
  • Do not backbite one another
• All mankind is created from one man and one woman, therefore, no one has superiority over another and noblest is he who is the most righteous.
• A true believer is he who believes in Allah, His message and strives in the path of Islam with his wealth and person in the way of Allah.

• Life after death is a reality and there is nothing strange about it.
• Allah has assigned two angels to each person for noting down every single word that he utters.
• Every disbeliever will be thrown into Hellfire and Hellfire shall be asked, ‘Are you full.’ Hell will answer, ‘Are there some more!?’
• Admonish people with the Quran and bear with them in patience.

• Surely the Day of Judgement shall come to pass.
• There is a lesson in the stories of Pharaoh, Ad, Thamud and people of Nuh.
• Allah, who built the heavens and spread out the earth, has assigned Prophet Muhammad ﷺ to be a warner for mankind.
• Allah is independent of people and all needs.
• Reflecting on the signs of Allah within ourselves and in creation itself.

• The reward for the righteous will be Paradise in which they will show gratitude for Allah’s graciousness while the deniers of truth will be put in Hellfire.
• Mission of the Prophet is admonition.
• Response to the disbelievers’ disbelief:
  • If they doubt the Quran, let them produce a scripture like it
  • Were they created without a Creator?
  • Do they possess the treasures of Allah?
  • Do they have other means to hear the facts about Allah?
  • Do they have the knowledge of the unseen? If so let them produce their proof

• Scene of the first revelation, brought by Angel Gabriel to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.
• Allah gave the Prophet a tour of the heavens, Paradise and other great signs.
• Lat, Uzza and Manat (goddesses of Arabs) are nothing but names invented by pagan Arabs.
• Angels have no share in divinity, nor can they even intercede without the permission of Allah.
• Do not claim piety for yourselves, Allah knows who is god-fearing and pious.
• No soul shall bear the burden of another; there shall be nothing for a person except what he strived for.

• The Day of Judgement is drawing near yet the disbelievers are not paying heed to the signs of Allah.
• ‘We have made the Quran easy to understand the admonition, so is there any who would take the admonition?’ This is mentioned four times.
• The story of Thamud and Lut who called their prophet liars to show how terrible was Allah’s scourge and how clear was His warning.
• Pharaoh’s people were seized for disbelieving Allah’s warning. The same warning has come to you, will you not take admonition?

• It is Allah who created man, taught him the Quran and taught him how to convey his feelings and thoughts.
• Allah is the Lord of the East and West. It is He who made the laws to regulate the oceans, its products and ships.
• All that exists will perish except Allah.
• No one can run away from the jurisdiction of Allah.
• Sinners will be punished in Hell and the righteous will be awarded Paradise.
• ‘Which of the favours of your Lord will you deny?’ has been repeated thirty one times.

• Scenes of Judgement Day when:
  • Some will be abased and some exalted
  • The earth will be shaken up
  • The mountains will be crumbled to scattered dust
  • Mankind will be divided into three groups: the foremost in rank and position, the common righteous people and the disbelievers
• Admonition to the disbelievers with the examples of creation.
• The testimony of Allah about the Quran.

• Allah created the heavens and the earth in six periods and has knowledge of everything.
• On that Day, the true believers will have their light shining before them while the hypocrites will have a fate similar to the disbelievers.
• Those who spend in charity will be repaid manifold and also be given a generous reward besides it.
• The life of this world is but play, amusement and illusion.
